abstract.p: Iron fertilisation of the high latitude oceans is a well-established biological mechanism to explain the ice age drawdown of atmospheric CO 2, yet modelling has so far struggled to account for a sufficient drawdown via this mechanism. Here, the authors propose that N 2 fixers, which inhabit the lower latitude ocean, made a significant contribution to CO 2 drawdown and so amplified the global response to iron fertilisation during ice ages.
